sn12.38:1.2: “Intend” (ceteti) and “plan” (pakappeti) play the role of “choices” (saṅkhāra), while “underlying tendencies” (anuseti) stand for “ignorance”. | This Sutta illustrates the threefold pattern (tivaṭṭa) into which dependent origination was later analyzed. The twelve factors are grouped under three headings: ignorance, craving, and grasping are “defilements” (kilesavaṭṭa); choices and continued existence are “deeds” (kammavaṭṭa); the remainder are “results” (vipākavaṭṭa). Within these groups we different synonyms or related terms are used in particular contexts (see eg. SN 12.19). The least fitting in this scheme is bhava, which includes all three, but is counted under “deeds” here as it connects grasping with rebirth.
sn12.38:1.3: That is, it takes rebirth in a new life.
sn12.38:1.4: It “grows” as the individual grows up and matures, leading to renewal of the cycle (see SN 12.64, SN 22.53, MN 38:28.1).
sn12.38:2.1: Underlying tendencies manifest as morally potent choices. But we usually don’t make such choices continually; they only occur from time to time. Much of the time there is no active volition, for example, when we are asleep. But so long as the tendencies are still there, one is not freed.
